Today we highlight Joanne Matias who retired in early 2020. Joanne, a graduate of the Johnson City Class of 1976, began her career at JC in 1989 as a hall monitor at the high school. She later became a teaching assistant in the library.

Joanne, encouraged by her peers, went back to school and earned her Bachelor’s degree to teach PreK-6th grade. She then went on to receive her Masters degree in Special Education K-12 and, in 1993, became a long-term substitute teacher.

In 1996, she was hired as a fulltime special education teacher in a program called Bridges, later to become Pathways. “My passion was to help students graduate,” she said.

Joanne said she misses her colleagues, her mentors and the students.

We thank her for her years of dedication to students and wish her the best in retirement.

JC 2nd-grade teachers Heidi Tiderencel and Erin Fahrenbach recently created a fun project for their students.
"Since we can't be physically with our kids at this time, we wanted to reach out to them in a virtual way and spend some "time" with them," said Tiderencel. "We read the book "Flat Stanley" to our class and then we sent each student a "Flat Teacher" of ourselves along with a poem. Their job was to take us on adventures with them over the course of a two-week period and then they were to write a story about our adventures. We just had our writing meeting this morning and the kids shared their writing. After everyone shared, Erin and I had a video of all the pictures and videos that we received. We hope you enjoy it as much as we did!" Johnson City Elementary School

We're pleased to announce Johnson City senior Matthew Pope, a member of Boy Scout Troop 110, recently achieved the rank of Eagle Scout.

To achieve the rank of Eagle Scout, Pope earned 30 merit badges demonstrating competency in a wide range of areas including camping, first aid, personal finance, personal fitness, citizenship and many others. In addition he completed a service project leading a team of 18 volunteers to renovate the entrance to Wolfe Park, a popular park for hikers in the town of Chenango. The project included removing years of accumulated graffiti, building new railings for the gazebo, as well as sanding and staining the gazebo and two swing benches. Congratulations, Matthew!

According to Perry, she found success with the project and we congratulate her for all her hard work. Great job, Erin!

We are proud to announce the U.S. News & World Report has ranked the Johnson City High School a 2020 Best High School. What does this mean? In New York state we ranked #403 and within our immediate region we are #7.

If you are wondering how these rankings are established it is based on several factors, some of which are student demographics and performance outcomes on math and reading state assessments, college-level exams (AP) and graduation rate.

This is an incredible honor for our students, community and all staff. From the custodians, grounds and maintenance staff who make the school safe and welcoming, the cafeteria staff who provide nourishment and kindness, the support staff who keep everything organized and running smoothly, and the instructional staff who impart knowledge and enthusiasm for learning to our students.

post_text: Representatives from Cornell Cooperative Extension Broome County visited the 1st graders today to talk about rabbits as part of the ongoing Ag in the Classroom program at JC. Students first listened to the story "Peter Rabbit" and then had the opportunity to see and touch a live rabbit. Mrs. Abbott's class met "Pierre", a breed of rabbit classified as a lionhead because of the mane-like fur around its head. The class learned that rabbits can reach speeds up to 35 m.p.h., baby rabbits are called kits (short for kittens), and, like deer, adult males are known as bucks and females are does. The visit ended with the students eating some blueberries and lettuce, a rabbit's favorite food!

post_text: High school students Selena Kasmarcik, Haleema Saadia, Taylor Blanton, Shanya Lassiter and Tu Meh recently participated in the first-ever County Executive's Challenge for Change. Under the guidance of high school history teacher Judy Gleason, the students put together a presentation that addresses the possibility of providing an opportunity for on- campus vaccinations to reduce the likelihood that a child will be excluded from school due to a lack of mandatory immunizations. They gathered school data, reached out to United Health Services and created a school survey. For their hard work, they won 1st place in the challenge and were awarded $1,500 toward continuing their endeavor. At its meeting on December 17, the JC Board of Education recognized the students for their impressive accomplishment. Stay tuned for more information about this ambitious group's continuing effort.
